title: (x) Design Museum - FF Schulbuch SÃ¼d {Jan Erdmann}
content:
Hey everyone, this is my first post, hope you could help me with this...

Just wondering what this typeface used for the DESIGN MUSEUM's identity is. I thought it could be some form of Din (because of the straight leg of the R) but the S is nothing like any Din, it has much more of an extreme curve.

[http://www.designmuseum.org/exhibitions](http://web.archive.org/web/20120111121245/http:/www.designmuseum.org/exhibitions "http://www.designmuseum.org/exhibitions")

sorry my terminology is terrible

any suggestions for typefaces of this sort would be a big help too. I'm currently working on typographically illustrating Nineteen Eighty-Four by George Orwell for my project at uni. Im looking for a very clinical looking font that has impact and authority on a page that can also represent the uniformity of life. I'm thinking maybe something mono-linear.

I would love to be able to afford Akkurat, but i am only a student.
author: wildlife_wilddeath

comments.content:
FF Schulbuch Sued Fett with alternative uppercase i.  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-schulbuch/sued-fett/](http://web.archive.org/web/20120111121245/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-schulbuch/sued-fett/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-schulbuch/sued-fett/")

Since then [I found out](http://web.archive.org/web/20120111121245/http:/www.fontshop.be/details.php?entry=17) that the Design Museum uses DM Schulbuch, a custom version of [FF Schulbuch](http://web.archive.org/web/20120111121245/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_schulbuch/), which is why there are a couple of differences as Jan pointed out.
